Comment: This variation of the Scandinavian Defence offers everything a good gambit should: a lead in development and lines of attack.  In other words, lots of fun for the aggressive player!

!? One of the perennial problems with this gambit line for black is white's space advantage in the centre, which is important I think to challenge at every opportunity.  This move of course enhances the pressure already being exerted all along the a1-h8 diagonal by black's g7 bishop.

Strikes a hard pace with respect to development without letting up on the pressure!  With the Scandinavian, I always go for tension and complication.  8... cxd4 merely allows white to precipitate a blood bath (9. Bxd4 Bxd4 10. Qxd4 Qxd4 11. Nxd4) that simplifies things to his advantage.

Strikes a hard pace with respect to development without letting up on the pressure!  With the Scandinavian, I always go for tension and complication.  8... cxd4 merely allows white to precipitate a blood bath (9. Bxd4 Bxd4 10. Qxd4 Qxd4 11. Nxd4) that simplifies things to his advantage.
Other moves are possible (e.g. 9. d5), but clearly white wants to relieve some pressure.
I decide to exchange queens seeing the opportunity not only to keep his king exposed in the centre a little longer, but also the additional opportunity triple up his queen-side pawns.
10. Nxd1 and black can strike back with 10... Na4 which forces white to concede his pawn advantage (for example, 11. Rb1 Bf5 12. Rc1 Nxb2).

The logical move to make given white's weakness on the queenside, and given how his pawns are lined up like ducks in a shooting gallery!  At this point, I would say that black has achieved equality with white.
